Definition: Toxicity is defined as something that makes someone want to quit a conversation because it is harsh, insulting, or unfair. You must sort the input statement into one of two categories: Toxic and Non-toxic.

Positive Examples.input:
Comment: Although it is not true that all conservatives are stupid people, it is true that most stupid people are conservative.

 John Stuart Mill
Positive Examples.explanation: This is a toxic comment because it is disrespectful.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Why? You just wasted  5 minutes of my life.
Positive Examples.explanation: This is a non-toxic comment because it is not rude or desrespectful.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: I personally know and work with Muslims. None of them cover their faces.
Negative Examples.explanation: This should be non-toxic because the comment only speaks about muslims but does not disrespect them.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: Glenn, why are you such a fool. Grow up!
Negative Examples.explanation: This should be toxic because it disrespects Glen.

Comment: Note to ignorant Associate Press and the equally ignorant Denver Post Editorial Staff. Micronesia isn't a country. Micronesia is a sub-geographic area in the Western Pacific. The U.S. Territory of Guam is part of Micronesia.  The Federated States of Micronesia are comprised of Yap, Chuuk, Pohnpei, and Kosrae. 

Moreover, it's the Republic of Palau. It's not a group of islands. It's a sovereign nation. Palau gained its independence on October 1, 1994. Some Americans would recognize the ferocious WWII Pacific battle of Peleliu. Peleliu is one of the states of Palau. When you visit Peleliu, you'll see beautiful memorials to the 2k+ U.S. Marines, Navy, and Army service members who were killed. You'll also see beautiful memorials to the 10k+ Japanese who died in the battle. Palau lost 10% of its population to WWII. Yet the Palauans respect the dead from both sides despite the immense tragedy. If they were Americans, they'd already be tearing down the memorials to the dead.

Comment: Yes, it is asinine to dismiss the entire conversation as stupid. These are very real and complex issues that aren't going to be solved by saying people should just get the right training or pick up their boot straps.

What does this say for working parents, or other people with fixed incomes and limited time? How should they acquire the necessary training to compete for a limited number of high-tech jobs? If denied education, their remaining choices are to go on welfare that depends on their unemployed status, or work in low quality jobs (quality having been driven down by the large amount of competition for the remaining jobs). Neither of these is a good option - quite frankly why should anyone want work their hands to the bone in dead-end jobs so the economy can screw them? The capitalist argument frequently forgets it's most potent weapon: incentive. 

UBI does not pay people not to work. It supplements income to guarantee security and inject market confidence.

Comment: At the risk of seeming unsympathetic --

As an Alaskan hiker who assumes there is no cell service, this woman appears not to have taken the basic precautions of bringing a compass and a map and the knowledge of how they work with her. Never rely on modern electronic technology when your life depends on it. I personally would not want to ruin the wilderness nature of the Appalachian Trail with a cell phone tower, but more than that, things happen and cell phones can get broken. Maps and compasses always work. And in a pinch, in the Lower 48, you can use an analog watch as a compass ... if you know what you're doing.

Also, as an Alaskan, the mention of Christopher McCandless resonates. That young man was wholly unprepared for what he attempted. He had no business being in the Alaskan wilderness and his failure to use basic commonsense got him killed. Ms. Largay doesn't seem to fall into the same camp of stupidity as McCandless.

Comment: In 2014, the Colorado Civil Rights Division appeared to make two conflicting and hypocritical rulings. In one case (Masterpiece Bakery) it ruled that the baker was wrong for declining to decorate a cake with pro-gay decorations; in the other case (Azucar Bakery) it ruled that the baker was well within their rights to refuse to bake decorate a cake with anti-gay decorations. Both cases involve the supposed right of each baker to pick and choose what artistic messages they wanted their artistic talents to convey. The CCRD apparently decreed that one "artistic refusal" was fine while the other "artistic refusal" was wrong when both "artistic refusals" involved the same issue: Gays. The State cannot decree that one form of "artistic integrity based on personal beliefs" is wrong while another is fine/legal without being what it is: The Colorado Civil Rights Division Where Hypocrisy Rules. I imagine the US Supreme Court is going to have a field day exposing this hypocrisy.

Comment: TOTALLY agree. I didn't wanna jump on it that hard, as Kami's a Broncos fan & agreed w/your overall point. 
The stat about teams' success when their bell-cow, or entire team, has X amount of carries, is silly, & reverse engineering.
Of COURSE teams win % is going to be generally higher in games where they rush it more.
1. When we're ahead, we're going to rush the ball more to milk the clock. I'll bet there's a GINORMOUS correlation between 4th quarter carries & winning %.
MORE importantly, 
2. Continuing to run the ball when we're averaging 1.5 yards a carry is going to ensure that we're continually be PUNTING the ball. 
And on the FLIP side, 
3. If we're averaging 6 yards per carry we're gonna have a LOT fewer 3rd & longs, & are gonna keep running it, since it's a LOT safer than passing. Turnovers aside, it's virtually impossible to LOSE a game when successfully running it.
THAT'S why teams who've won have more carries. Not because they rushed it just to hit 20 carries.

Comment: Ha!  I like the “budding journalism career” bit. I think it’s fair to say I haven’t done too badly in my many decades in journalism.  And I’ve spent the last 18 months working with the homeless and homeless providers, so I’m relatively akamai on this subject.  You elide the differences between the chronically homeless and the rest.  I do not.  Most of the homeless are not chronically homeless – indeed most of the homeless never end up on the street.  They couch-surf, live in their cars or spend a few weeks in a shelter.  However it most certainly is true that ‘‘most of the chronically homeless have severe mental health or drug addiction issues.’’ The official count on O‘ahu is that, of the 1,939 unsheltered homeless on Oahu in the 2015 Point In Time Count, 599 suffered from severe mental illness, and 514 were chronic substance abuse issues.  Moreover the addiction numbers are way low because they are self-reported.  Most of the homeless I encounter on the streets smoke ice.

Comment: The cost of medical care for schizophrenia may not be the greatest burden for families. The effects of the illness can be devastating for family members, too. Hopes and dreams for a loved one can be destroyed. Paranoid schizophrenia is particularly difficult to treat because clients may resist treatment and not take medication.

"... so treatment focuses on eliminating symptoms with antipsychotic medications and psychosocial therapy."

Antipsychotic drugs are imperfect, not equally effective for all clients, and they all have side effects - some potentially serious or particularly difficult to accept. Elimination of symptoms is only a goal.

The meds do not cause people to become violent. The mentally ill are no more likely to commit violence than the population as a whole. In fact, they are actually at greater risk of violence exacted upon them.

Comment: This play must be touring again as Lepage is giving interviews an April of 2017. I saw it last year and thoroughly enjoyed it. Like others in the mostly white Vancouver audience I leapt to applaud at the end.  Later, I looked up this phrase "speak white" and its history, and started to feel angry. I'd been had. The poem in question "Speak White" is yet another rant by a wounded Quebec psyche about how the English horribly suppressed them. "Speak white" basically meaning "speak English." 

I am an English Quebecer from a lower-middle class background a few years older than Lepage from a community in Montreal. I NEVER heard any English person I knew or encountered use the phrase "speak white." When I researched it after seeing the play, I found few references to its use. I'm sure it was used, but I can't prove it was uncommon and I suspect Lepage can't prove it was common. However, it feeds into the pequiste mythology about Quebec needs to be its own nation.

Comment: Most vessels that currently load in Vancouver go to refineries in Washington State,California or Hawaii, according to Thomson Reuters Eikon shipping data.
The Port of Vancouver, which houses Kinder Morgan's marine oil terminal, said it expects nearly 400 crude and chemical tankers a year under the expansion from 100.
The largest-sized oil tanker that can dock in Vancouver is an Aframax, which can carry 500,000 to 700,000 barrels. Vessels at the port can only be loaded up to 80% capacity due to depth and other restrictions, meaning a vessel can only be filled to around 550,000 barrels. 
As long as the port can only take Aframax, it will remain largely "uneconomical" for exports to head to Asia. Traders said the price of Canadian crude shipped to Asia needs to be low enough to offset the cost of shipping across the Pacific on smaller vessels.
Crude oil exports to countries other than the U.S. represents only 0.8% of Canada's total crude oil production, around 25,000 b/d on average.

Comment: While I agree that technology offers both extraordinary opportunities and challenges for continual education, I also feel promoting social skills and professional etiquette could equally impact personal development; put your phone away, turn off the tech, and have a conversation whilst looking someone in the eye. Genuine, personal relationships (those not facilitated solely or in large part by technology), and social/self awareness could stand to improve alongside one's ability to manipulate software.

In-person communication/mentorship, in addition to the electronic delivery of information, is also a method one can use to cultivate life-long professional/personal growth/success. 

Don't get me wrong, I love tech when used responsibly and with balance; however, it's cumbersome to see how it can become a crutch, barrier, and something many have come to depend on for the majority of their interactions and/or learning. 

Mentorship comes from people, not a box, electronic or otherwise.

Comment: The graphs answer your first question.   

As far as the CO2 goes, 250 ppm is within the normal range of CO2.  The average CO2 on the planet has fluctuated between a low of about 180 ppm and a high of about 280 ppm, with the average being 220 ppm for at least 800,000 years, and some experts say more than 3 million years.   The planet hasn't seen 250 ppm since before the industrial revolution.  The CO2 was at its cyclical high of about 280 ppm when humans began burning fossil fuels.

CO2 has not stopped driving the heating of the planet nor has it stopped at 400 ppm.   The CO2 today was recorded at 402.58 ppm at one recording station and we are entering the time of the year when CO2 rises the most - fall through spring.  We will probably never see CO2 below 400 ppm again.  

https://www.co2.earth/daily-co2?global-co2-board.html

You're correct, under preemption the state could put some kind of marker on State ID's or DL's for prohibited persons and require either to be shown at purchase. Comment: Sen. Bert Stedman, R-Sitka, has been critical of the current tax system, known as Senate Bill 21 or the More Alaska Production Act (MAPA), since it was first approved in 2013. He said the issue is larger than minimum tax or no minimum tax: the issue is the credits.

“If we’re in the $40 price range for the next 12 to 18 months, we’re going to cripple the treasury for five, six years,” he said.

That’s because whether or not the state hardens the floor, the credits don’t go away – they’re carried forward into future years. If companies take major losses at low oil prices, they can use that to reduce their taxes for years to come.

Stedman said that for all its faults, the previous tax system, called ACES — or Alaska’s Clear and Equitable Share — allowed the state to make up that money if oil bounced back, imposing much higher taxes at high prices. “We can’t afford $35 and $40 per barrel oil. Because we can’t recoup it on the upside to repair it.”

Comment: Yes, I agree that I'm doing something most people wouldn't. And I do borrow against my home with a HELOC.  I've now done it three times in seven years.  The first time, during the financial crisis in 2009, paid off so handsomely that it funded several years of retirement.  The second time, pretty much nothing happened -- no meaningful gains or losses and I sold the dividend stocks at break-even.
I don't think this is as risky as many others seem to.  The interest rate on my HELOC is currently 3.2%.  I pretty much tune out the market unless I can buy quality dividend paying stocks (big banks, BCE, Telus, Fortis, and some quality investment trusts when I can get a dividend that covers the 3.2% interest, plus inflation (currently 1.5%), plus a safety margin.  In February, 2009 when it looked like the financial world was ending, I bought shares of Bank of Montreal, for example.  Its common shares were paying a 9.6% dividend.  BMO has paid a dividend longer than any other company in Canada.

Comment: If you read this far into an article about the environment, you are probably someone who cares about making progress on this difficult issue.  You should be concerned about PSE's "Energize Eastside" project, which is opposed by CENSE, Sierra Club, 350 Eastside, and Protectors of the Salish Sea.

Why do these organizations oppose a transmission line?  Because PSE's customers will pay more than a billion dollars for this project over its lifetime through higher electricity bills.  Once we commit that amount of money to old technology, there will be no need to invest in smarter technology which would reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

What are the smarter options?  Demand response and batteries, which can store excess wind and solar electricity.  Instead of firing up a gas plant, batteries can release stored electricity during periods of peak consumption when the sun isn't shining or the wind isn't blowing.  Batteries would give us better reliability for less money.

Comment: Typo correction is a tricky thing for us, since we rely on peer moderation.

What if someone were to write a perfectly civil comment, get it through peer review, and then use the edit function to write something really nasty or threatening? Or what if they first write something like, "Dog food tastes awful," get a ton of affirmative replies, and then edit it to say, "Dog food tastes great"? 

One option would be to put each corrected comment through the full peer-review process, but that would mean you'd need to rate three comments every time you wanted to correct a spelling error, which isn't a great experience.

This is one reason we give you the editable text field one last time when you're asked to rate your own comment (the other reason is that you might reconsider what you've written, having just been through the review process for other people's comments!)

Any further thoughts on this are very welcome! We're new and have a ton of updates on the way.

Comment: Very good story with Sr. Stella Storch and the work that is being done with orphans in Tanzania.  They are working with teaching sewing to girls and have a carpentry school for boys.  This is creating real opportunity where there was none.

I am old enough to remember when we had "home ec" in high school for girls and "shop" for boys.  I realize times have changed but these still seem like basics to me.  More, we have focused high school so much that it is primarily college prep with too little attention given to preparation for those jobs that are not college centered - especially the trades - plumbing, electrical, machine tooling, etc.  Not sure I think high school needs to go back to cooking and sewing for girls, but do think both boys and girls need better trades prep - or maybe just the basic life skill of knowing what tools to use for routine household repairs.

Comment: I think you're on to something here, Mo. I don't understand this ugly phenomenon either, but I think the things you mentioned contribute to it. 

I'd add the immediacy of social media. In the era of letter writing, many an angry letter was torn up before it was mailed once the writer cooled down and thought better of their first impulse. Now so much goes out that's unfiltered and undeveloped, sometimes with tragic consequences.

Distance is another factor. It's easy to forget that the person on the other end of a hateful message is a human being. Like the general who orders the firing of a missile from 1,000 miles away, it's easy to harm another when you don't have to witness the results.

These liturgical shamers are critiquing isolated moments that validate their biases. But no single photo captures the whole truth, especially when it's viewed outside its original context. Community worship is an intimate act, and those on the outside should be circumspect in their judgments.

Comment: The "bundling" is quite different here.  In the U.S. it was a bundle of many different mortgages that were resold as a high-grade investment, even though mort of the mortgages in the bundle were not of very good quality.

The "bundling" discussed in this article is two loans for a single person, one a regular mortgage and the other essentially being an unsecured loan used for the downpayment for the mortgage.

That being said, the underlying issue isn't entirely dissimilar in that you have people who can't really afford the house they are buying, and therefore at a high risk of defaulting, obtaining loans where the details are intentionally obfuscated from lending regulators.

Comment: When I saw the highlights of this game last night, I was reminded of why the Ducks were a national powerhouse during the Chip Kelly and Marcus Mariota era and why they were so exciting to watch -- football played at a high-skill level. Having a great coach and a great quarterback on a team makes all the difference in college and professional football (e.g., the New England Patriots with coach Bill Belichick and quarterback Tom Brady).

I think Mark Helfrich is a good position's coach; he was once the quarterback coach before Chip promoted him to offensive coordinator. But based on last season and three games into this season, it's becoming clear that Helfrich is just not a head coach. The position requires many abilities: recruiting, player evaluation and development, team organization, managing position coaches and coordinators, and inspire, motivate, and discipline young players in their late teens and early 20s. Helfrich has demonstrated that he is below average in these key areas.

Comment: With talk of infrastructure spending and private investors comes the inevitable talk of toll roads and user fees, but how else do we think this will be paid for. Infrastructure such as roads,sewers, bridges etc. have been allowed to deteriorate in this country as provincial governments always found something else to spend the money on. Now many of our provincial governments are up to their ears in debt and have no money to fund these projects. We, or at least the governments have delayed these projects where certain areas are becoming dangerous.
  We would all howl if our taxes are raised in order to cover the costs, and many would complain if there were cuts to services, so sharing the cost and passing the cost on in part to those who use things like roads and bridges, seems like a reasonable solution.

Comment: I would characterize the second term as past recovery, but I agree it is difficult to truly assess things. To me, the good is the unemployment rate which will be difficult for Trump to improve on, at least without causing inflation. The "meh" is the other measures of employment such as U6, which have steadily gotten better but could still go from 9% to 7% or so. Also "meh" (I'd rate it a "bah" until recently) is wage growth, which has been flat until this past year. Really, all I could hope for from Trump is a moderate decrease in U6 and continued wage growth, all which would be expected in a near full employment situation anyway.

Comment: Garneau says the illegal migrant situation is "extraordinarily well managed."  He's correct, if extraordinarily well managed means the efficient provision of welfare, housing and medical care to anyone who enters Canada illegally from the US.  He's also correct if extraordinarily well managed means processsing their residence claims with so many delays, appeals, and court challenges that the vast majority will never be ordered to leave.  And he's right if extraordinarily well managed means most of the few who are actually ordered to leave will just defy the order and stay.

This begs the question: why does Canada pretend to have a border or immigration laws?   We don't secure the former or enforce the latter, but we spend a lot of money pretending that we do.   Why not just accept the position of our political and judicial elites that every single person on the planet has the right to live in Canada?  Sure it would wreck the country faster than Trudeau will, but it would be honest.

Comment: I see a couple of problems with your plan.  To start with, Pebble contains fairly low grade ore, so tens of billions of tons of ore would need to be relocated for refining - I don't think they will want to be hauling tens of billions of tons of material very far for offsite extraction.  Also, pebble east will be an open pit mine, and about 10 billion tons of overburden needs to be removed and stored locally - I don't think they will be hauling billions of tons of overburden away.  finally, when they are done, they will have a pit 2 miles wide and thousands of feet deep.The extraction chemicals are a big problem, but they are far from the only problem associated with the mine from an environmental standpoint, and hauling billions of tons of ore to an offsite location for refining will never be economically viable.

Comment: The reason for the train drivers strike is that they don't want to open and close the doors at the stations. They want the person with the paddle to signal that it's ok to close the doors and leave the station. The union argument is that it isn't safe, but the driver only operated trains have been in existence for over thirty years and the same union agreed to the use of DOO trains in several contracts in the past few years. No one was losing their job, the closers, for want of a better word, were to be deployed to work in the carriages on the train.  As for the Tube, well they're closing underused ticket offices and putting these people out into the stations to help customers. It means they can't hide from anyone, again, none are losing their jobs, but they've gone on strike.  It's the usual Luddite reaction of militant, Trotskyist union leaders, self admitted by the way, to changes in the working environment that most of us have no choice about.

Comment: While these games are hardly new, the district is forced into such a move by contract language and an obstinate legislature that utterly fails, every year, of doing the most basic damn function of their job. The legislature ought to be ashamed. And the school district should reevaluate every single program and position, stop the mission creep, realize they aren't a social services agency, and get their priorities straight. The games need to stop.

Comment: If you look at your mortgage payments in reverse, i.e. how much money you end up getting by "investing" in your mortgage, it is a no-brainer. 

Suppose you have a 3 1/2% mortgage. You are making your payments with after-tax money, so ... la-de-da, if you go back and slap on the taxes you've already paid on your income (which is where your mortgage payment comes from),  if your net income is about 70% of your gross income, pre-tax you would be paying 5%.

Now if you were to suddenly get a windfall from somewhere and "invested" it into paying off your mortgage, your mortgage payments disappear. So your mortgage "investment" will yield you 5% with the mortgage payments you no longer have to make. 

Okay, 5% isn't bad. But you can do a bit better if you pick the right stocks, right? But the nice thing about your mortgage "investment" is that there is no risk; your mortgage payments will absolutely disappear. 

So how many no-risk savings accounts or GIC's are around that will give you 5%?

Comment: The statement originated with early pistols and rifles.

For a Flintlock rifle there was no safety, instead there was a half-cock position of the hammer - which is also the origin of the saying "Don't go off half-cocked".  To load the Flintlock, you first "locked" the hammer back to the half-cock position.

The same applies to early pistols.  No safety, just a half-cock position.  If the pistol was loaded, and half-cocked, if you dropped it, the hammer was not supposed to be able to strike the firing pin.

Comment: You forgot to mention that the ACLU was also an intervener in 2010 in support of Citizens United law suit, where the US Supreme Court decided that money is a form of free speech.  Like many free speech zealots, the ACLU was unable to see the wood for the trees.

There is no such thing as ABSOLUTE freedom in any human civilization, and I think we should stop pretending that there is absolute free speech until something goes wrong.  The known and predictable consequences of unfettered free speech need to be accounted for before the fact.  I admit limiting free speech is very difficult, but I think it is irresponsible not to do so.  Although Canada is more restrictive, the US does not have unfettered free speech either.

If free speech is the be all to end all in support of democracy, consider how the Citizens United decision has undermined democracy.  It is no longer one man/woman one vote, but one dollar one vote.  The US is no longer a functional democracy.

Comment: I don't share your views that more money in primary care will reduce the need for life-saving surgical procedures.  That is based on my real world experience in performing surgery and seeing that over 90% of cases could not be prevented.  For many health concerns prevention isn't as effective as we all hope it could be.  I do agree we need to be careful about funding sexy innovations that are costly.  The article doesn't say that every urology program in Canada should get a robot.  He is saying that a single large academic teaching program in one of the top 10 medical schools in the world should probably have one.  Then maybe the evidence that everyone is looking for could be obtained and the procedures validated.  Worst case scenario is the process of innovation and teaching is supported where it should be.  The absence of evidence is not evidence that we shouldn't use robots in surgery.  How do we get the evidence we need for our patients in Canada if we don't have access?

Comment: I disagree with you opinion.  Trans Mountain makes great economic sense because it provides strategic alternative outlets for Canadian oil, which means the US can no longer force a discount based on a captive market.  Whether or not it makes "ecological" sense will not be known until and unless there is a significant marine spill.  In my view this is unlikely, but if that unlikely event that occurs we should be prepared with money in the form of a performance bond by the owners of the oil and with resources in the form of a marine response unit to minimize any damage.

Comment: Long said he reached out to “hold” Dao and was able to pull him away from his window seat on the aircraft and move toward the aisle.----At that point Long made a big mistake in handling the passenger. But the staff should have known it as it is a basic rule regarding the removal of passengers from a flight.

Comment: Monica, insightful as usual. Some folks say that without access to priests salvation is impossible, since only priests have access to God and can get folks to heaven. IMHO this is bizarre to say the least. I know a lot of folks who are much closer to Christ and more Christ-like than I am. If access to priests is such a requirement, then a lot of good folks don't have a chance.  This does not seem much like the Jesus of the gospels.

Pope Francis has spoken out against clericalism, and he said sometimes it is the people themselves, not just priests, who will not let go of it. While we might need some form of priests, in the sense of leading in prayer, etc, we do not need the clerical caste. Many small groups choose their prayer leaders themselves in different ways, and it seems to work well. 

IMHO the basic question is what does it mean for me/us in my/our particular circumstances to be a disciple of Christ.  This is a good question always, but especially these days.

Comment: I think the one thing we all can agree on is Electoral College is no longer necessary.  It was designed as a way to determine the President when it would take a week to tally all the votes.  I say let's try a 3 vote system.  Electoral would be the House vote each state's votes based on the number of registered voters.  Then have the Senate vote with each state getting an equal vote of 2 per state. Then add the national popular vote.  The President would be determined on who can win two (or all three) out of the three votes.

Comment: I would define Islamophobia as the irrational fear of Islam, the operative word being "irrational".  I'm as opposed to racism as anyone, believing that it is the greatest evil that ever beset the human race. However, a close second would be terrorism. The natural fear and anger that results is very much rational. The answer to reducing racist "thinking" is not government mind control. Rather it involves the sanctioning of behaviours that produce this thinking. These behaviours include all actions that deny basic human rights. This is where there is role for the government. For example, in the case of terrorist activity, why does Canada not have a law that makes it a crime to belong to or support a terrorist organization, so the crime can be prevented rather than just reacted to ? This is the kind of government intervention we need, not more naïve legislation to control our thoughts.

Comment: I was thinking of the mention of general welfare in the preamble. 

Preambles are not law but they are part of constitution (defined as "the introductory part of a statute or deed, stating its purpose, aims, and justification." )

If the aims of the constitution are to promote the general welfare then it naturally follows that trying to prevent people from dying in the street from cholera (or being burned in fires or poisoned by toxic food or being ripped off by banks, etc.) might support this goal.

Comment: Five years ago I bought a 1999 Taurus from a co-worker (got it checked out by a local mechanic first, who gave it a clean bill of health) for about $1,800. Three years ago, when my son turned 17, I gave it to him; he'd done most of his learner driving on it, liked it, and found it plenty roomy (at 6' 7", this is an issue). He had fun installing a great new sound system in it, and had to replace a couple of minor things (he bought the parts used and did the work himself), but other than the usual ongoing things (oil, fluids) it's running fine.

When I gave my son the Taurus I bought a 2004 Sorrento from a friend (got it checked out; again, fine) for $2,000. Had to buy new summer tires this year, but again, apart from the usual ongoing things it's been great. 

I chose to buy used for these prices not because I'm poor, but because I'd rather spend my money on other things. If the vehicle is sound and gets me safely from A to B, that's good enough for me.

Comment: DaSkier,
I agree with you that stupid actions that harm to plants and animals has to be considered prior to any mining or other project that can have a devastating effect on nature now and for future generations. I would add to what you said, that not only local citizens should have a say in it but other people who may be affected further down the line and future generations. 
If Canadian mining companies dump tailings into the water on the Canadian side and it flows down to the American side, where salmon spawn, it will kill off the salmon and other wildlife that depends on the water. 
Strip mining is one of the most harmful types of mining there is. It literally destroys, beyond all imagination, entire landscapes. I grew up where a huge strip mine was started in the 1950's.
By the time the mining company pulled out, entire mesas had disappeared and piles of yellow and black cake was all that was left behind. The earth was poisoned killing the orchards, fields and people near by.

Comment: "Canadian bank shares are trading at significantly higher levels than their U.S. or European rivals if you compare price-to-book-value ratios"

This is not entirely true nor does it signify what the author says. US Banks in general pay much lower dividends than Canadian banks - B of A 1.2%; Citi .95% v. BOM 3.76% - their lower price-to-book - BofA .93; Citi .83 v. BOM 1.46 reflects this. If you consider a US bank that pays a higher dividend, Wells Fargo, div is 2.74% and price-to-book is 1.39 - which looks much like BOM and other Canadian banks.

I don;t disagree that a recession will cause lower bank income and lower share prices - this is obvious and inevitable - but simplistically comparing one measure and making broad conclusions that are incorrect makes this article's conclusions suspect. C-, Mr. McGugan.

Comment: The way I read the article is that the authors are basing the idea that breastfeeding is not the root cause, but rather another potential obstacle to overcome.  It is like the chicken and egg scenario.  Does unsuccessful breastfeeding cause depression or is the difficulty that the person is already depressed the issue.

I think what they are saying is that if you can catch and deal with the underlying causes of depression than difficulty in breastfeeding causing anxiety will be a lesser problem

The authors stance seems sound in that is based on research, but that does not mean it is the end of things.

I do agree with your premise that society does go thru phases.  Right now breastfeeding is in, whereas many times in the past it was out.  We should not judge, but rather as a society we should be looking at solutions that provide the best outcomes.  Breastfeeding is very beneficial to baby and mother, but that does not mean in all cases it is the best choice.

Comment: The subsidies are a remarkably inefficient way to increase uptake.

If government wants to invest in EVs, there are two sensible courses of action.  First, encourage private industry to invest in supporting infrastructure.  We need quick charge stations along our major highways, since range anxiety is stopping many people from considering EVs.  Second, invest in post secondary research projects to improve batteries.

If we must subsidize purchases, let’s do it by waiving the GST or offering interest free loans.  Direct payment to owners is unfair to those that cannot profit from the advantages of owning an EV.  Sort the range problems through robust infrastructure and improved batteries, and the market will take care of itself.  Subsidize well-heeled owners and EVs will remain a niche product.

Comment: But given that a large part of undocumented immigration is due to people overstaying their initially legitimate visas (essentially deciding to not go home as required), the normal visa program has to remain closed, as it has been for a long time, to anyone who would have a high probability of benefitting from remaining in the US. 

Based on a government report issued in Feb. of last year, approximately 415,000 people whose visa was supposed to end in 2015 have decided to stay in the US. That's just for visas expiring in 2015. Presumably a similar story exists for every year. It adds up fast. 

This is a judgment call that State has to make on every visa application, and given they can't know what is in someone's head, they have to be convinced by objective data that the person would not benefit nor want to stay here as compared to returning home. 

This gentleman can't satisfy that criteria. So he doesn't get a visa. It's not political.

Comment: I agree, Hugh, that humans don't "really wish for more diversity," especially when it involves "constantly attacking them." 

Diversity shouldn't be so much a value as a strategy. The benefit of enduring the discomfort that comes with diversity (in a healthy environment) is resiliency -- a broader range of experience and perspective gives us more options to overcome adversity. 

John Chapman is remembered as Johnny Appleseed because apples are heterozygositous. Each apple has seeds that will make many other kinds of apples. Natural diversity. So apple orchards planted by ole Johnny survived and grew. His reputation grew with it, thanks to hard cider, but that's a different story. 

Fast forward. Now commercial apple trees are all grafted, so the growers know what sort of apple tree they'll get. Without heterozygosity, apple trees need more pesticides than most other fruit. (Most of this is from Michael Pollan's "Botany of Desire.")

Diversity widens our adaptive options.

- Don Kahle

Comment: TD, having actually taught Econ 101 for the University of Maryland, I think I can say for sure that Trump and the GOP's hatred for ACA is a primary reason ACA has not been more successful.  Actually with all ACA's economic flaws, it has been a successful program.  The major flaw is it's lack of control mechanism for actual medical costs, thus increased insurance company premiums.  The Medical industry lobbyist have been very good at insuring their representative medical companies have remained free of cost controls.  Germany has a medical system that works, it's an excellent model that insures everyone, includes the private insurers in the process and actually provides better medical care for a lower GDP cost to the taxpayers. Unless by "cars" you mean just regular passenger vehicles and not the wide variety of other vehicles on the road (trucks, vans, construction equipment, semi tractors, delivery vehicles, maintenance vehicles, etc.).

And even for regular passenger cars, I think it will be a slow shift.  A 50% market share for new sales of EV passenger vehicles will be a big challenge, but certainly possible if things keep improving. But anything sooner than a decade for that goal is overly optimistic IMO.  

Which still means the majority of all vehicles on the road will remain ICE for at least 2 or 3 more decades IMO, since they have a 10-15 year lifespan, and since non-passenger vehicles make up a large portion of vehicles on the road.

Comment: This is known and has been known for decades. The larger the insurance group, the more affordable coverage becomes. This is a primary reason why the ACA doesn't work, because it still doesn't allow small companies and individuals to combine with larger companies to create large pools. It still doesn't allow across-stateline purchases, which would allow such groups to grow. To mandate that everyone have to get insurance, but then do nothing about the silos of coverage that were pre-existing and already driving up premiums, was stupidity on a stick. Really, our government officials who are supposedly in charge of "fixing" the health insurance "crisis" are so woefully ignorant of economics and basic market forces that they now think they've encountered a new idea that will save a small number of people a lot of money.

Open the marketplace for the rest of us. Get rid of the coverage silos and watch the cost of medical insurance gradually moderate, resulting in reduced premiums.

Comment: I considered filing a formal complaint about this article but decided a comment would suffice.
Doug Saunders is either being purposely dishonest or simply doesn’t comprehend when he draws repeated parallels of the IRA campaign to the current reign of terror in Europe. Based on Hanlon’s Razor of never attribute to malice that which is adequately explained by stupidity I’ll assume he’s not being malicious. 
The IRA’s three largest bombings in England, the Manchester bombing which Sanders refers and draws parallels to, the Bishopgate and Canary Wharf bombings killed a combined three people despite each being literally a hundred times as large as last night’s bomb. (2000lbs vs 20 for those keeping score at home).
The reason why only three people were killed was because the IRA’s goal was not to kill civilians, very much unlike the current score of bombings. They went so far to call in warnings before and wait for civilians to be evacuated. Does that sound like a fair parallel to ISIS?

Comment: Fastracks was a great boost to getting real mass transit in Denver, but since it was laid out along highways and rail lines we now have to develop housing and businesses around the stations for it to maximize it's utility. 
What the focus needs to be now is increasing the quality and frequency of service in places where there is already demand. The coming BRT on Colfax is a great example. It's already the busiest route in the city, already surrounded by some of the densest neighborhoods where people can easily walk to and from the bus. These are the type of routes that don't need massive subsidy. It's the long distance suburban ones that cost way too much. Giant park n rides and low ridership routes get all the money, when dense central neighborhoods that rely on transit and actually want it get dirt on the side of the road to sit in while they wait for a bus.

Comment: Sorry but I just don't buy the canard that "it will get there somehow". Given the state of a lot of Canada's rail tracks and the frequency of derailments and the fact that dangerously unstable crude was allowed to be hauled on trains with a single operator over MM&A's loucy tracks and parked overnight on a mainline at the top of a grade is ludicrous! We need a LOT more regulation on rail and truck transfer of hazardous goods, not to gut regulations on pipelines - we're not Nigeria!

All employment is voluntary.  No employer is required to hire you, and you aren't required to accept any employer's offer.  Both sides have to agree that it's a fair deal. Comment: I guess it just goes to show that the Hawaii Government practices the motto: "Do as I say, not as I do!" 

For years the State has come out on the winning side of Court rulings in its favor & every time they would say: "You may not like the ruling, but you have to respect it."

Now, when the State is on the losing end of the court ruling, it wants to engage in the act of splitting hairs to continuously re-litigate the issue! What kind of leadership is this?

The bottom line to this DHHL issue is that DHHL is the only department in the State that has a direct link to the Hawaii Constitution, as part of the compact with the Federal Government to assume the fiduciary duties of the Hawaiian Homes Commission Act of 1920. That fiduciary duty includes, but is not limited to: "Adequately funding the administrative costs of DHHL".

The Ige administration may not like having to fund DHHL, however, it is the law. One way to kill a department is to NOT fund it. Is this the plan?

Follow the law!

I  may always be an "outsider "in Alaska,  but I  don't disparage the state and it's people.  I  urge Alaska residents when they venture "outside " , to come visit our beautiful state and it's people - you will be pleasantly surprised if you allow yourself to be. Comment: Several reasons. Border officers have a legal power to refuse entry and direct persons back that inland officers do not possess.

Also once a person is physically within Canada, Charter rights are engaged and there is a right to have eligibility for a refugee claim assessed and then a hearing before an independent tribunal (the Refugee Protection Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board).

Back in 1985 the SCOC determined that the lack of an oral hearing for a refugee claimant before an independent tribunal was unconstitutional Singh v Canada (Minister of Employment and Immigration), [1985] 1 S.C.R. 177.  Singh determined that any person in Canada even without legal status was protected by the Charter.  That decision was based on section 7 rights to security of person and fundamental justice.

Comment: Sure obstruction of justice is an impeachable/indictable offence. It's a criminal act drawing very stiff penalties. But does Trump's statement, "I hope you can let it go." rise to the level of obstructing justice and committing a criminal offence? Of course not.

When Nixon was impeached for obstructing justice he was overtly doing so by refusing to hand over legally subpoenaed documents. Trump isn't withholding evidence, squashing an investigation, blackmailing an investigator or anything else. He made an open-ended comment to Comey that could be interpreted in a number of ways.

The standard of proof of a criminal or impeachable act is "beyond a reasonable doubt." That's a very high standard of proof. It would require far greater evidence than an alleged memo written by Comey, which no one has seen, about what Trump said.

Comment: I'll agree that this study has some serious flaws, but some of your criticisms seem rather off the mark.
For example, having no data on career or vocational training does not mean that that wasn't "worth study", but rather that it was unavailable for study. This is an important distinction (and points to why such studies are so difficult to conduct, really).
Second, income is clearly reported—in fact, even if one doesn't read the text, there is a graph titled "Wages of 2005 Graduates" that shows the growth in wages of various educational groups over time.
Finally, as is nearly always the case with stories like this, part of the problem is that it's a news story, not the report itself. The full report is linked in the story, however, and contains much more information, including on issues you claim were not covered.
The takeaway? Before criticizing research (rather than news about research), it's always good to read the research itself.

Comment: This issue is framed, incompletely, as 'religious freedom against gay and lesbian rights'. To be clear, TWU's Community Covenant also denies entry to heterosexuals who do not subscribe to the university's prohibition against sex outside of marriage. 

Religious freedom includes the right to be agnostic. Section 2 (a) of the Charter has been interpreted by the SCC to include protection from the imposition by others of religiously motivated sanctions against conduct that is otherwise legal. The covenant infringes therefore on the rights of heterosexuals broadly, and - given the obvious double standard governing premarital sex - discriminates against women in particular. 

TWU, of course, claims exemption on the basis it is a private Christian university. What the SCC must decide is whether that exemption compels the legal profession and justice system, which ostensibly stand for fairness and equity, to accept the graduates of a university that openly repudiates those principles.

Comment: This is a very good interview with James Hansen on the human created factors in super storms like Harvey.  https://www.democracynow.org/2017/8/30/ex_nasa_scientist_james_hansen_there

He make three points: One consequence of global warming is that for every degree centigrade that global average temperatures increase, the air contains 7% more moisture, simply because warmer air holds more water vapor. There is more water in the air to fuel these deluge storms, creating the downpour, now over 52 inches. Another is sea level rise. The global average is 8 inches, but that's the average. The sea level rise in the Gulf of Mexico in the areas hit by Harvey is higher, "a good foot," according to Hansen.  This additional water vapor fuels the strength of the storm as well as contributes to the unprecedented rain, and the storm is larger and more powerful.

Much stronger, wetter storms on top of a foot of sea level rise in recent decades have created this particular climate catastrophe.

The Federal government wanted to provide additional welfare services to 'Indians' on reserves, and they contracted with the provincial governments to provide these services, given the provincial governments' existing experience in providing such services.  The agreement between the governments stipulated that these additional services would only be provided to 'Indian' Bands after the Bands were consulted.
2. The Federal government did not consult the Bands, and the provincial governments provided the services, one of them being foster/adoptive care of children at risk.
3. Two written submissions from a Band chief and council member stated ( 49 years after the fact) that if they had been consulted, they would have informed the fostered/adopted children of their parents' culture, and that they would be welcome to come back to the reserve.
4. Since the children were not informed, this is considered damage.

continued..

Comment: This is the big last gasp for big cable TV - the writing is on the wall. Comcast's Xfinity X1 isn't going to survive either.

When the big networks and the big specialty cable content channels offered by Discovery, Fox, Smithsonian, etc., which are linked to cable TV contracts finally realize their market share is disappearing at the same rate as that for big cable TV, they will disconnect from cable TV only contracts and allow paid & free Internet streaming without cable TV subscriptions.

When that happens, big cable TV is dead.

Comment: It is virtually oxymoronic to think of Trump in the context of "good". There is a tendency to project value and virtue on our leadership, absolving ourselves from real "followship" and responsibility. 
Personally I want to see Trump impeached, trampled in the dust and feel the meaning of rejection.  But, if good people find the peace and acceptance he rejects; if good, enterprising people take up the "planet saving" he rejects;  if good people find the acceptance, civility towards and among those Trump foments dissent and hate, he might just not feel the pain he deserves. 
That might be the price of decency.

Comment: Boulder...My maternal grandparents lived there from 1945 until their deaths in 2010 and 2011.  My paternal grandparents settled there for good in 1964 (one is still living). My parents are BHS graduates, as are several aunts, uncles, and cousins. None of the aforementioned people, in my time on the planet, ever once complained about having lived under a Chinese-communist style repressive system. They were free to pursue their education and gainful employment, come and go from the city as they pleased, eat where they wanted, and hold whatever opinions they desired. My paternal grandpa was known to call into Alan Berg way back in the day.  No one from the BPD ever showed up at his house to arrest him for not having the right opinion. I've never seen someone get flattened by an army tank in Boulder. As a matter of fact, I bet you would like to see city law enforcement bash protestors...

In short, if you want to compare the two, you need to have more than just pop taxes and safe zones.

Comment: The grid isn't overloaded - several provinces, including Ontario, have seen declining demand. Others have invested billions into expansion and require customers to amortize their outlay (cough, MB hydro).   Winnipeg is about 25km from end to end so 150k range should be fine, and plugins are ubiquitous (allowing you to charge, but more importantly, keep the battery warm). The city's isolated location also limits "road trip potential"  - if faced with the prospects of driving 8 hours to get to Saskatoon or Thunder Bay, my answer is "why"? 

Transit and incentives are great, and I hope they do, but the dominant market share is always going to be automotive, and that's as much a consequence of our built form as anything else.

Comment: I personally don't understand opiate addictions. I've been prescribed opiate pain meds after surgery and was very glad when I could stop taking them when I felt better. I don't think that banning them is the answer because most people are responsible enough to use them as prescribed. I don't think that patients should be given refills on their pain meds.
I think it's interesting that one of the reasons many cities have legalized pot is to give addicts a legal alternative to addictive drugs. That idea completely derails the gateway theory but it seems to be helping. I don't think that it's fair to label people who are taking medications "druggies". Especially if they're taking prescribed medications. Bullying people and threatening them with incarceration is only going to cause depression and make their problem worse. There is no magic treatment fix. Addicts have to have will power and a strong and positive support system that helps them regain the will to live.

In essence it will be as if you are saving over $1,000+ per month. After paying the same amount each month, after 5 years you will have paid over $70,000 of the principle. Paying a mortgage is a form of forced saving for most owners. This also doesn't take into account any increase in the value of the property. Buying will always be better than renting.

Comment: How well does pumped storage work in flatlands? Yes nukes run at full load 99% of the time, while fossil generation caries the swing in load. The efficiencies of your other solutions is very poor at this time. I am not claiming that renewable won't work sometime in the future, but at this time there is no alternative to redundancy in fossil generation. The thermal stress of rapidly changing the output of the fossil plants to handle the rapid generation output load swings of solar or wind is causing much damage that is expensive to repair or replace. Where things can go if the technology reaches a point of usability is one thing. What we can do now is another thing. Just because someone claims there is a 200 mpg carburetor, doesn't make it true. Where is all of this technology you speak of? I expect things to be different in 100 years, but I don't expect to be around then. One question I have is what will covering the planet with solar cells or massive wind farms do to the climate?

Comment: We don’t need to worry about any single station and we don’t rely just on land stations. Over 90% of the  warming from greenhouse gases is absorbed by the first 2000 ft of the ocean! {From multiple publications, such as Gleckler et al, “Industrial-era global ocean heat uptake doubles in recent decades” in Nature Climate Change Jan 18, 2016}. Subsurface ocean temps are measured in an entirely different way.

Land, sea surface, and lower atmosphere temperatures measured from satellite also show the warming. And, we see it in other ways: about 90% of glaciers retreating, Greenland melting more and more, and about half of recent sea level rise is due to warmer temperatures (thermal expansion). There is a conspiracy: The earth is conspiring to show us it is warmer!

Comment: Like most of the other 7 million people in the GTA, mandating winter tires would be both unsafe and unfair.   Because in almost every winter in the last 34 years, there have been fewer than 4 days a year when there is actually snow on the roads! Some years there are zero days!  So while I might be safer for those 4 days, the rest of the winter I would be driving on tires on wet or dry roads that do not perform as well.  The other remedy is just to slow down a little. Driving slower is far safer that changing tires.
Also, would someone please explain the temperature difference issue?  I understand that winter tires are more pliable at colder temperatures, BUT, once my car is driving on roads, even at the worst temperatures, don't my tires heat up very quickly?  
I grew up in Saskatchewan, lived in Winnipeg and London Ontario, where cold and snow are the rule, and of course, winter tires are better there. But not in most of the GTA where my snow blower rusted away from lack of use.

Comment: This column is a classic "fish story"  --  mostly nonsense.  Fish farming is illegal in Alaska.  (On the whole West Coast, it turns out only WA and BC allow it.)

According to the Alaska Dept of Fish & Wildlife website (caps mine):

"Salmon farming began in the Pacific Northwest in the 1970s. On those tickets, the airline runs a real risk of having an unpaid seat fly because of a last minute cancellation. However, there is no excuse for overbooking non-refundable tickets. In those cases, the seat is paid for whether there is a bum in it or not. 

No passenger with a non-refundable ticket should ever get bumped.

Incumbents rule the day because basically no one in Hawaii gets involved in politics, from voting to running for office. I can tell you first hand as I have been on the primary ballot last election cycle. This election I worked the polls on the North Shore and was shocked about the questions the handful of voters that walked in had. Some of the questions were "There are more parties on the ballot?" usually followed by" I never heard of any of these before". Also " not sure why I came in here today, no one is running against the guy I voted for." This one was shocking I overheard from a father and son " just don't vote for ____ his name sounds Samoan." Green Party was on the ballot and I'm not sure why as it said "No candidate running" after the party name. I was asked by a voter "which one of the guys is against rail?" Hawaii redefines voter apathy.

Comment: Let me give you some of my logic. 
Towards the late '60s it was time to consider likely places to emigrate to. The short list of countries to polish one's English included (in alphabetical order) Australia, Canada, New Zealand, South Africa and the United States. 
Looking at the globe, the global order at that time and my moral compass, the choice in '69 was Canada. Absolutely the correct and logical choice for me.

Comment: Alfred,
I'm often saddened when I see the church come out with a position like this.  The sadness comes less from a inconsistencies between what the church puts forth and science, or the many questions that can arise when one tries to apply logic to what the church teaches.   Rather, the sadness comes from the realization that what we've learned from science since the last such position taken offers church leaders a chance to dig deeper, to expound in more depth, and to take us somewhere new.

Here, the church has a great opportunity to reflect on the nature of death, the soul, and an afterlife.  Which is more important: that we understand the details of how "resurrection" works with our physical bodies, or the very concept that there could be something more, even if we don't fully understand it, and perhaps how we might begin to think about that 'something more?'  Common sense and science leave a TON of questions to be answered.  Why not take us to new theological insight?

Comment: Part 2
In the final year of HS, I rather formally explored the Ukrainian Redemptorists and Basilians as well as the Jesuits and other RC orders. (The notion of becoming a eparchical priest never entered by mind.) I was totally turned off by the visits to the Basilians and Redemptorists (years later, learned from a Basilian friend my negative vibs were well founded); but when I visited the Jesuits, I felt attracted. At the time, it was the promise of a rigorous 14 year training regime that drew me in; today I am convinced the Lord's objective for me was Ignatian spirituality, a form of mystic listening prayer.

 Once in the Jesuits, I very quickly acquired a desire to function as a Ukrainian priest, and this was fully supported. It was the reason why I went to NYC for further studies to be near a group of Easter Rite Jesuits, known as the Russian Jesuits. Again total encouragement. I was sent to Europe to study Byzantine history, but never completed that program. Left to get married.

Comment: "Why should the constitution protect their benefits?"
You are blaming the judges for something out of their control because you don't understand why the constitution did so.  Okay.  I'll try to explain it to you but I expect it'll be wasted effort.
We want judges to come to a decision based upon the law not politics. Most notably to avoid any sense of being beholden or influenced by another branch of government, say the legislature. We want an independent, insulated judiciary that makes decisions free from any outside concerns. This means we don't want the legislature to be able to retaliate against any unpopular or unwanted decisions by cutting judge's pay.  Nor do we want to provide the legislature with the means to threaten judges from making such decisions.
"Why isn't it protecting all employees' benefits?"
If you can come up with acceptable public policy reasons to protect all employees feel free to share it.  It was tough enough for the unions to get recognition of labor rights.

Comment: I guess I'm in an unusual position as a liberal Catholic who loves both the Ordinary AND Extraordinary Forms of the Roman Rite.  Liturgical diversity is a bedrock of the Catholic tradition, and, as others have said, unity does not mean uniformity.  In response to Father Reese's contention that the Tridentine liturgy is still being allowed only because some people "find change difficult," I ask him how he would explain the appeal of the Tridentine Mass and pre-Vatican II practices such as the Ember Days to someone (using myself as an example) who was born some time after the 1970 implementation of the reform and did not experience the Extraordinary Form until I was in my thirties?   Both the Pauline Mass and the Tridentine Mass are living liturgies.   Phasing out the latter is precisely the kind of small-minded authoritarianism about which liberal Catholics tend to complain when such authoritarianism (e.g., banning female altar servers) is carried out by conservative Catholics.

Comment: Don't ever knowingly fly with this if you can avoid it -- especially in older planes (DC10s, 727s etc) as cabin pressure adjustment systems weren't as sophisticated as they are in more recent models.   The ear drum could burst.   Any big change in altitude over a short period of time can do the same.   Elevators in very tall buildings, for example.

One thing that often helps ear congestion (as long as it's just temporary congestion)  is to soak towels or paper towels in boiling hot water and then place them in a mug, cup etc.   Let them cool very slightly so there isn't a lot of steam coming off them and then gently place the cup over the ear.   Don't press it right against your head;  what you want is for the warmth and moisture to get inside your ear -- you don't want a complete seal around the ear.   This is a good trick for those times when you have flown with congestion not realizing how bad it is until take-off.  Flight attendants will usually be able to assist.

Comment: If the deposit had kept up with inflation, it would be 25 cents. That the government has to levy a potential fine for people to return their bottles is an example of why some government interventions are justified.
Throwing something "away" (it never really goes away), represents an externality. The true cost of something is not in the original price. Unless there is a disposal cost, the consumer is making a purchase decision based on an artificially low price. That's an inefficient marketplace. 
When we do anything that externalizes the cost of something, we're bypassing pure capitalism. Pollution dumped into our air and water has costs. If you're not paying those costs upfront, someone else is. Pollution kills.
Certainly we cannot stop all pollution. But we can regulate it. We can make business pay, which passes the cost to consumers. Is one a capitalist if one does not pay the true cost. Maybe it is a kind of theft.  We steal the savings from those who pay the cost in health issues.

Comment: In the end, I don’t agree with ANY increase in the GET — but I have to see this bill as a win for Jill Tokuda. If it wasn’t for her, lawmakers would have never bothered to look “outside the box” and tapped the hotel room tax.

By doing so, they limit an extension of the 0.5% GET rail tax to three years. If it was me, I would put it all on the hotel room tax — and let the 0.5% GET sunset in 2027. But we don’t want to displease Mufi and the Local 5, now, do we?

It hurts to see our sick and elderly — most already struggling on a fixed income — continue to pay a 4.712% tax on their groceries at the checkstand. As a direct result of this bill, they will do so until 2030. If the federal government shuts down, and their social security checks are delayed, pray for them.

Comment: You should get a quote on what it will cost to swap out for new batteries and factor that into your $2 fill up cost.  Batteries have considerably lower life than a gas engine, so don't be fooled by the relatively low cost of charging.  You have to factor in the life span costs.  Sure the govt gives you a break on the original cost of buying the batteries, but no subsidy exists for the 2nd or subsequent go around.

Currently we have a fleet of battery powered drivers and drills for work.  When the battery goes, which is maybe 2 years, we throw away the tool and buy a new one.  Why the cost of replacement batteries is almost equal to the cost of a replacement tool with new batteries.  It just does not make economic sense to buy replacement batteries.

I see a whole slew of junk electric cars, simply because no one will want to replace the batteries.

Comment: "This would include the requirement that taxpayers pony up additional funds if the return on PERS investments is below the unrealistic levels set for the system, but no counter-balancing mechanism if returns are higher than expected."

Misleading.  If you (as a PERS employee) chose the "variable" interest rate option, you rode the market.  You got all of the gains on the up side (and some were considerable in the '90s) and ate the losses on the down side ( the dot com bubble of 2000 and the crash of 2008).  If you selected the "fixed" option, you were guaranteed a minimum rate, but you would never receive all of the earnings in an up year if they exceeded that minimum.  The board would assign a portion to the fixed accounts, but not all earnings.  

As for "unrealistic levels set for the system,"  up until the 2008 crash the PERS fund averaged over 10% gains during the life of the system with a fixed guarantee of 8%.  "Unrealistic" seen with today's eyes, but reasonable in years past.

Comment: I absolutely am not minimizing the struggles people had when they were coming up and I have no doubt that it's always been hard to establish yourself as an adult.

Still, I don't like "ever it was thus" because it absolves people from analyzing specifics. It's the same when people say "Vancouver has ALWAYS had  expensive real estate". Yes, but it's never been CLOSE to as bad as it is right now. Few would argue "ever it was thus" comparing 20-somethings in the Great Depression to 20-somethings in the 1960s. So why suppose it's impossible that it's harder now than it was in the 90s, 80s, 70s, etc.?

It would be immensely helpful if people took a look at the duration of our present economic funk, the relative permanence of available employment, and the level of compensation available for work versus the cost of education and the cost of living. There is a growing lost generation, and we haven't even seen a collapse of real estate yet (which powers much of our economy in some provinces).

Comment: If you want to know why the  Jones fire is not being controlled any quicker than it is, read it from the Incident Commander's point of view.   https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5494/
The "critical resources" he is referring to are hotshot crews that have the knowledge and training to burn the indirect firelines that have been constructed in on the leading edge of the fire.  The Jones fire is fifth in the regional priorities (behind a fire far from any population centers on the Colville Indian Reservation) so they are not getting the shot crews need to do the burning and contain the fire.  
Besides having to deal with the heavy load of dead and down and standing dead trees left from the Clark Fire (never salvaged logged because it was in a Late Successional Reserve), many of the logging roads in the fire area had been decommissioned meaning they had to be reopened with heavy equipment delaying line construction that may have controlled the fire at a much smaller acreage.

Comment: Correction to this article:

Community members did not advocate keeping the current system, which is NOT analog. It’s a hodgepodge of meters including some analogs retrofitted with transmitters. It’s the transmitters which are failing. Folks at the meeting suggested replacing the transmitting meters which are at the end of their life (5-15 years) with reliable, durable analogs. Tried and true analog meters will last 40+ years, as some Port Angeles residents know who still have perfectly functioning analogs that are 50 or 60 years old. 

Smart meters, as an industry executive testified before Congress, have a 5-7 year life. Investing millions in this “smart” technology will inevitably mean higher utility bills for ratepayers, and need replacement before we can blink. 

Yes, there are hundreds of millions of smart meters installed worldwide, creating a mountain of problems… and that’s why the pushback is mounting. 

For another perspective on this meeting, see the 11/1 Leader article.

Comment: I think you underestimate immigrant thinking. I'm an immigrant myself, albeit from quite a while ago and I would not like to see a flood of immigrants from the same background as myself coming here and either deliberately or not, changing the nature of Canada.  It's not a simple "pull up the drawbridge" reaction. I came here because Iliked the idea of Canada, not because I was running away from anything. I wanted to contribute to Canadian values and progress. I oppose immigration which would tilt our society away from its steadily progressive, economically-viable position. In my opinion, the best way to solve this issue is to discontinue all the various kinds of visas in favour of only one - a 5-year non-renewable immigrant visa. During the five years the immigrant would have to apply for full citizenship, the test for which should include a very tough test of fluency in at least one of our official languages which would make integration almost inevitable.

Comment: Roy, I am for mass transit that will reduce traffic congestion.  My problem with the Rail Project--it is not intended to reduce traffic.  DOT director Wayne Yoshioka wrote in final EIS, "traffic congestion will be worse in future with rail that what it is today without rail.."  Later,l Table 3-12 shows that compared with today's daily auto trips, if we do not build the rail project, we will experience a 23% increase in trips, while if we do, we will experience a 21% increase in auto trips.  I live in Ewa Beach and member of Neighborhood Board.  The narrow rail corridor is not a practical alternative to our residents.  Mayor Caldwell, at the Kapolei Forum, when asked about the lack of parking around the Kapolei rail station offered an unattractive solution--riders will park(cost), take a shuttle from parking lot to rail station(cost), ride the rail(cost), take a shuttle/bus to their final destination(cost).

Comment: As far as I know, there is no information publicly available about either the nature of Santiago's war experience or the nature of the mental health care offered to him in Anchorage during 2016.  Relatively few soldiers even in a war zone actually experience combat.  And it seems, at least at this point, quite possible that Santiago refused any treatment that may have been offered.  

More fundamentally, there is an obvious fallacy involved in listing, as Jim Gottstein does, the medications allegedly taken by notorious mass killers as if that proves the meds caused the killings.  Many millions of these prescriptions are written each year without, apparently, resulting in criminal acts.  And they are especially likely to be prescribed for people already suffering from some type of mental illness.  So it's not very surprising that some cases of violence are going to correlate with them, the way some deaths from cancer are going to correlate with chemotherapy.

Comment: First - ACTUALLY cut the budget. With the exception of DOT, which has seen about an 18% reduction, most other programs have not been cut by more than single-digits. Walker originally said 25%. Total cuts have been about 10%. This brings us back to the bloated budget we had in 2009 when Parnell took office and starting spending the savings.

Second - renegotiate the production credits so that we're paying something closer to what Iraq pays - $2 a barrel instead of $46 a barrel. Maybe $10 a barrel for dealing with the NS weather would be fair.

Third - base taxes on what is standard in other oil-producing countries. Take an average. Right now, Alaska taxes lower by far than almost any other country.

Fourth - make sure we're getting every dime of the royalty oil sales due us.

Fifth - do the sovereign wealth fund with citizen oversight.

Then, and only then, should an income tax be looked at and it should be subject to voter approval and include a tax rate cap.

Comment: Eli,
I don't think it's fair to assume that our strike led to any additional bombings by Assad: he's been doing this daily for far too long.  The strike by the US was (from what I can tell), designed to make it clear that using WMDs crosses a line, and when Assad does so, he will pay.  IF the strike does nothing more than stop him from using WMDs again, it will have accomplished it's goal.

I don't think ANYBODY believes that's "the answer," to Assad, but if it stops him from using more WMDs, it will have been worth it.  I actually suspect he'll "test" us one more time.  And if we respond, again attacking ONLY military assets, but in a way that hurts his military even more, I'm guessing that will take WMDs off the table there for good.  A lousy way to have to do it, but better than an all out invasion...

Two rapid heartbeats beating in pain

Blood on hand, to ring with finger
Warm gently bundle of feathery fun

Bird on ground, brick in hand
Hammer with head, dead, dead, dead

Head full of shame, shaking frame
Flickering eyelash, tear stained cheek
Sobbing heart, heavy feet

Comment: You've called them "false statistics" without hearing where they came from.  This bespeaks rigid anti-fact ideology, and I suspect that no source will satisfy someone intolerant of opposing views.  

Hepburn, Lisa M. and David Hemenway. "Firearm availability and homicide: A review of the literature." Aggression and Violent Behavior. Vol. 9, 2004: 417-440.

National Research Council of the National Academies, Committee on Law and Justice. "Firearms and Violence: A Critical Review." The National Academies Press: Washington, D.C., 2004.

Most of the studies I've seen don't meet the causal test, because of determining factors such as trying to compare urban to urban rates with urban to general rates are lacking in data.  The reason they are lacking in data is because of lobbying efforts by the NRA to prevent such studies (by denying funding).  So, while some types of violence can be directly attributed to gun ownership, others can't be; you're partly correct, but I stand by my claim.

Comment: Megan you are doing a great service to the City and our residents by taking this CERT class and writing about your experience. I know your articles will inspire more people to sign up for these vitally important classes. In my job doing communication for the city I see how important trained CERT volunteers are to our response efforts. Every disaster is local and neighbors can make the difference in every disaster situation - a trained individual in each neighborhood will make a huge difference.

Our city is very lucky to have Christina Brugman directing the CERT program. She is making a real difference in the community. 

People can find the list of preparedness classes at http://kirklandcert.com/ and they can sign up for the City's weekly email, This Week in Kirkland, to get notification as to when new classes are open. Sign up at www.kirklandwa.gov/thisweek.
